Introduction

Porphyrias are a group of rare metabolic disorders characterized by defects in heme biosynthesis that lead to the accumulation of intermediate substrates.  These substrates are toxic to the nervous system and skin, resulting in neurovisceral attacks and/or photosensitivity.  It has been suggested that these conditions may have inspired vampire folklore.

Pathogenesis and clinical manifestations



Heme is a molecule that consists of a ring-shaped structure (porphyrin) surrounding an iron atom.  It is synthesized primarily in the liver for incorporation into cytochrome P450 (CYP450) enzymes and in the bone marrow for incorporation into hemoglobin during erythropoiesis.  Heme production involves a series of 8 enzymatic reactions (

figure 1
), and the disruption of any of these steps can lead to the accumulation of porphyrin intermediates, which are toxic in high concentrations and create unique porphyria subtypes.



Because porphyria is a rare condition, only the most common subtypes (eg, acute intermittent porphyria [AIP], porphyria cutanea tarda [PCT], erythropoietic protoporphyria [EPP]) will be discussed in detail.

Step 1:  Delta-aminolevulinic acid synthase (ALA synthase)



Reaction:  Glycine and succinyl-CoA combine to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) via ALA synthase, the rate-limiting step in heme synthesis.  This step occurs in the mitochondria and requires vitamin B6.



Porphyria subtype:  There are 2 unique forms of the ALA synthase enzyme: ALA synthase 1, which is expressed in all tissues, and ALA synthase 2, which is expressed only in erythroid progenitor cells.  The gene for ALA synthase 2 is located on the X-chromosome, and gain-of-function or loss-of-function mutations can lead to 2 distinct diseases:



  • A gain-of-function mutation leads to an overproduction of downstream porphyrin intermediates that overwhelm the capacity of the last enzyme in the reaction series, ferrochelatase.  Ferrochelatase normally attaches iron to protoporphyrin IX to form heme.  When ferrochetalase is overwhelmed, excess protoporphyrin IX accumulates.  Protoporphyrin IX is hydrophobic and deposits in the lipid bilayer of epidermal cell membranes.  Upon exposure to sunlight, protoporphyrin IX generates reactive oxygen species that cause oxidative damage to surrounding tissue.  This condition is known as X-linked protoporphyria.
  • A loss-of-function mutation leads to a decrease in the formation of all porphyrins, and therefore, heme synthesis.  Without sufficient protoporphyrin IX, excess iron accumulates in erythroid progenitor cells and results in sideroblastic anemia (ring sideroblasts can be visualized on special staining (
    image 1
    )).  Because there is no accumulation of toxic porphyrin intermediates, this condition is not a porphyria.

Step 2: ALA dehydratase



Reaction:  ALA is converted to porphobilinogen (PBG) via ALA dehydratase.



Porphyria subtype:  A mutation in the gene for ALA dehydratase can lead to the accumulation of ALA, a rare condition known as ALA dehydratase porphyria.  Both ALA and PBG are neurotoxic in high concentrations and can lead to autonomic dysfunction, neuropathy, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Step 3: PBG deaminase



Reaction:  PBG is converted to hydroxymethylbilane via PBG deaminase.



Porphyria subtype:  A mutation in the gene for PBG deaminase can lead to the accumulation of PBG and its precursor, ALA.  Patients are often asymptomatic unless triggered by certain factors that increase heme synthesis (ie, induce ALA synthase activity).  Common factors that can increase heme synthesis include certain medications that induce CYP450 enzyme production (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
), alcohol, tobacco, physiologic stress (eg, surgery, fasting), and increased progesterone during puberty (
figure 2
).



When these conditions are present, ALA synthase activity outpaces PBG deaminase activity, resulting in the accumulation of toxic intermediates in tissues, particularly the liver.  This is known as acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), an autosomal dominant condition and the second most common porphyria subtype (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
).  Patients typically present in their 20s-30s with episodic symptoms, which can last days to weeks.  These episodes are characterized by:



  • Neuropathic abdominal pain:  Typically diffuse, severe, and accompanied by vomiting, constipation, and hypoactive bowel sounds.  Because the pain is neuropathic, there is typically no tenderness on palpation.
  • Peripheral neuropathy:  Includes sensory (eg, tingling) and motor (eg, weakness, which can lead to respiratory failure) disturbances.
  • Autonomic dysfunction (eg, tachycardia, diaphoresis, tremors).
  • CNS involvement: Can manifest as seizures and neuropsychiatric symptoms (eg, anxiety, insomnia, mood fluctuations, restlessness, hallucinations).
  • Urine changes:  Patients develop red-tinged urine that darkens on exposure to light and air due to the oxidation of excess PBG (
    figure 3
    ).


Of note, PBG deaminase activity can be within the normal range in young erythrocytes, waning only as the cells age.  This initially normal enzyme activity may in part explain why patients with AIP do not have hematologic symptoms (ie, the erythrocyte progenitor cells can produce the necessary amounts of heme).

Step 4:  Uroporphyrinogen III synthase



Reaction:  Hydroxymethylbilane is converted to uroporphyrinogen III by uroporphyrinogen III synthase.



Porphyria subtype:  Reduced activity of this enzyme affects mostly erythrocytes.  Biallelic mutations result in congenital erythropoietic porphyria.  In this condition, hydroxymethylbilane accumulates and is metabolized to other porphyrin precursors that cause:



  • Anemia:  Excess porphyrins cause hemolysis and ineffective erythropoiesis.
  • Photosensitivity:  Due to excess porphyrin deposition in the skin, which, upon exposure to sunlight, generates reactive oxygen species that can cause significant tissue damage beginning in infancy.
  • Reddish-brown tooth discoloration (erythrodontia) due to excess porphyrin deposition in the teeth.

Step 5:  Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD)



Reaction:  Uroporphyrinogen III is converted to coproporphyrinogen III via uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD).



Porphyria subtype:  Dysfunction of hepatic UROD causes porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), the most common porphyria subtype (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  Unlike the other subtypes, which are caused by genetic mutations, PCT is usually caused by environmental factors (eg, iron excess from hemochromatosis, infections [eg, hepatitis C, HIV], ingestion of ethanol or estrogens, tobacco use, exposure to halogenated hydrocarbons [eg, pesticides]).  These conditions inhibit hepatic UROD activity, allowing the accumulation of porphyrinogens upstream of the enzyme.  These substrates are carboxylated to photosensitive porphyrins that are transported to the skin.  Clinical symptoms generally manifest when hepatic UROD activity reaches <20% of normal:



  • Vesicles/bullae:  Upon exposure to sunlight, porphyrins generate reactive oxygen species that damage proteins in the basement membrane, causing epidermal separation and blistering.  Patients develop increased skin fragility with painless vesicle and bullae formation on sun-exposed areas (eg, dorsa of the hands, face) (
    image 2
    ).
  • Facial hypertrichosis
  • Lesions often scar and form both hypo- and hyperpigmented areas (
    image 3
    ).  This disfigurement and subsequent avoidance of sunlight by patients has been speculated to be the inspiration for vampire folklore.


Rarely, patients with PCT have an underlying heterozygous mutation that decreases their baseline UROD activity to 50%.  Therefore, these patients are predisposed to levels dropping below the 20% threshold due to environmental factors.



In PCT, UROD activity in erythroid progenitor cells is normal, and heme manifestations are uncommon.

Step 6:  Coproporphyrinogen oxidase



Reaction:  Coproporphyrinogen III is converted to protoporphyrinogen IX via coproporphyrinogen oxidase.



Porphyria subtype:  Impaired coproporphyrinogen oxidase function causes hereditary coproporphyria, which presents with systemic manifestations (similar to acute intermittent porphyria) and photosensitivity (similar to porphyria cutanea tarda).

Step 7:  Protoporphyrinogen oxidase



Reaction:  Protoporphyrinogen IX is converted to protoporphyrin IX via protoporphyrinogen oxidase.



Porphyria subtype:  Impaired protoporphyrinogen oxidase function causes variegate porphyria, which presents with prominent photosensitivity.

Step 8:  Ferrochelatase



Reaction:  Ferrochelatase attaches iron to protoporphyrin IX to form heme.  Ferrochelatase can also attach zinc to form zinc protoporphyrin.



Porphyria subtype:  Ferrochelatase deficiency leads to the accumulation of metal-free protoporphyrin produced by erythrocyte progenitor cells in the bone marrow.  The circulating protoporphyrins deposit in the skin, and patients present similarly to X-linked protoporphyria.  Ferrochelatase deficiency causes erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP), which typically presents in early childhood with diffuse erythema and edema within minutes of sunlight exposure.  Vesicle/bullae formation and residual scarring are minimal in EPP, likely because protoporphyrins are hydrophobic, resulting in different tissue distributions.

Risk factors



Risk factors for developing porphyria depend on the specific subtype.  Most of the subtypes are associated with an underlying genetic mutation.  Additional risk factors include environmental factors associated with symptom onset (eg, viral infections, alcohol ingestion).

Porphyria classification, testing, management, and prognosis



Each of the 3 most common porphyria subtypes has a distinct clinical presentation that is classified based on where (hepatic or erythropoietic) the toxic intermediates initially accumulate.  Recognizing the clinical pattern helps direct the initial workup:

Hepatic accumulation



Acute porphyrias (eg, acute intermittent porphyria [AIP], presenting with acute neurovisceral symptoms):



  • Diagnosis:  Initial diagnostic testing includes measuring total urine porphyrins, ALA, and PBG.  Confirmatory diagnostic testing includes genetic testing and demonstration of decreased PBG deaminase enzyme activity.
  • Management:  Directed at inhibiting ALA synthase 1 (rate-limiting enzyme) to reduce the formation of toxic porphyrin intermediates.  Strategies include:
    • Hemin infusion:  Hemin is an oxidized form of heme that downregulates ALA synthase 1 production and is administered during acute episodes.
    • Dextrose infusion:  Inhibits peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-gamma, a transcription factor that induces synthesis of ALA synthase 1, which reduces porphyrin synthesis overall.
    • Avoiding triggers, including CYP450-inducing drugs (eg, most antiepileptics, griseofulvin, rifampin), alcohol, and tobacco use.
    • Other supportive care measures (eg, beta-blockers for tachycardia, gabapentin for neuropathic pain) may be appropriate.
  • Prognosis:  Episodic attacks can be life-threatening (eg, due to respiratory failure), but with prompt recognition and appropriate management, the prognosis may be good.


Blistering cutaneous porphyrias (eg, porphyria cutanea tarda [PCT])



  • Diagnosis:  Initial diagnostic testing includes measuring total urine or plasma porphyrins.  If elevated, individual porphyrins should be measured.  PCT can be distinguished by the elevation of highly carboxylated porphyrins (eg, uroporphyrin, heptacarboxyl porphyrins) relative to other porphyrins.  Ferritin levels (indicative of iron stores) and liver enzymes are usually elevated.
  • Management:  Identifying and treating triggers (eg, antiviral therapy against hepatitis C, serial phlebotomy to reduce excess iron stores) and avoiding sunlight exposure.  Hydroxychloroquine can be used to mobilize accumulated porphyrins from the liver, facilitating excretion from the body.
  • Prognosis:  PCT is treatable, and patients generally have a normal life expectancy.  Relapses can occur if they are re-exposed to conditions that inhibit UROD activity.

Erythropoietic accumulation



Nonblistering cutaneous porphyrias (eg, erythropoietic protoporphyria [EPP])



  • Diagnosis:  Initial diagnostic testing includes erythrocyte total protoporphyrin.  If elevated, the results should be fractionated, which shows a large percentage of metal-free protoporphyrin and some zinc-protoporphyrin.  Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis.
  • Management:  Primarily involves lifelong photoprotection.  Afamelanotide, which binds to melanocortin receptors to increase melanin production and skin pigmentation, may be utilized to increase tolerance to sunlight.  Beta-carotene may also be utilized to improve sunlight tolerance.
  • Prognosis:  Patients with EPP generally have a normal life expectancy, but the lifestyle modifications necessary to reduce pain with sunlight exposure may impact quality of life.

Summary



Porphyrias result from enzyme defects in heme synthesis, leading to the accumulation of toxic porphyrin intermediates that can cause neurovisceral and/or cutaneous symptoms.  Acute porphyrias present with severe abdominal pain, neuropathy, and psychiatric symptoms.  Cutaneous porphyrias present with photosensitivity that may cause pain and/or skin blistering.  Diagnosis involves laboratory assessment of porphyrin levels.  Management is dependent on the specific subtype and may include hemin infusion and avoiding triggers.
